facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1128 of 1965 was an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 17, 1962 of the Bombay High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 29 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1128 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 17, 1962 of the Bombay High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 29 of 1960. T. Desai, R. Ganapathy Iyer and S. P. Nayyar, for the appellants.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2, the firm of Chandmal Manmal, was indebted to the 1st respondent, Central Bank of India, Aurangabad branch.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought, by special leave, from the judgment of the Bombay High Court dated December 17, 1962 in Letters Patent Appeal No. 29 of 1960. Respondent No. 2, the firm of Chandmal Manmal was in debted to the 1st respondent, Central Bank of India, Aurangabad branch.

facts.text: On March 11, 1955, the first respondent filed Civil Suit No. 28/1 of 1955 against the second respondent for Rs. 14,541/- and odd in the Court of Subordinate Judge at Aurangabad.

anchor.surface_text: On March 11, 1955 the first respondent filed a suit being Civil Suit No. 28/1 of 1955 against the second respondent for recovering a sum of Rs. 14,541/- and odd in the Court of Subordinate Judge at Aurangabad.

facts.text: On the application of the first respondent, an order for interim injunction was passed in respect of certain properties belonging to the second respondent.

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the first respondent an order for interim injunction was passed in respect of certain properties belonging to the second respondent. The Court had ordered the second respondent to furnish security for the amount of the decree which may be passed against the firm in the suit.

facts.text: On April 28, 1955, Jogilal Mulchand, one of the partners of the second respondent, furnished security by creating a charge on his immovable property, a house at Aurangabad.

anchor.surface_text: On April 28, 1955 Jogilal Mulchand, one of the partners of the second respondent furnished security by creating a charge on his immovable property, which was a house at Aurangabad. After the security bond was furnished, the attachment was released.

facts.text: After the security bond was furnished, the attachment was released.

anchor.surface_text: After the security bond was furnished, the attachment was released. The security bond furnished by Jogilal Mulchand read as follows I, the Defendant No. 2 therefore stand as a surety and declare that if the Honble Court decides the suit against the Defendants, he will abide by every order passed by the Court and if he fails to do so, then I. defendant No. 2 stand as surety to the extent of Rs. 20,000/-  Rupees Twenty thousand  in O.S. companyns and declare that I shall pay the amount of security into Court and for fulfilling the same I create a charge on my one pucca two storied house possessed by me known as Chandi Posh bearing No. 167 situate at Kasba and Taluka Vijapur, District Aurangabad of the value of Rs. 25,000/ If I fail to pay the amount of the security, the Court will then be entitled to recover the amount of the security from the property hereby charged

facts.text: On April 30, 1955, the Subordinate Judge granted a decree against the 2nd respondent for a sum of Rs. 14,541/- and odd.

anchor.surface_text: On April 30, 1955 the Subordinate Judge granted a decree against the 2nd respondent for a sum of Rs. 14,541/- and odd. The 1st respondent filed an application for execution of the decree Linder s. 145 of the Civil Procedure Code.

facts.text: The house which was charged under the security bond was sold in auction sale and purchased by Girdhardas, confirmed by the Court on August 14, 1958, with sale proceeds deposited in the executing Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the execution of the decree the house which was charged under the security bond was sold and one Girdhardas purchased it in auction sale which was companyfirmed by the Court on August 14, 1958 and the sale proceeds thereof were deposited by the said Girdhardas in the executing Court.

facts.text: On August 17, 1958, the Sales Tax Officer, Aurangabad Circle wrote a letter to the District Judge, Aurangabad pointing out that a sum of Rs. 9,672/- and odd was due to the Government from the second respondent on account of arrears of sales-tax for the years 1950-51 to 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: On August 17, 1958 the Sales Tax Officer, Aurangabad Circle wrote a letter to the District Judge, Aurangabad pointing out that a sum of Rs. 9,672/- and odd was due to the Government from the second respondent on account of arrears of sales-tax for the years 1950-51 to 1955-56.

facts.text: On September 23, 1958, the District Judge sent a letter to the Subordinate Judge asking him not to pay the sale proceeds to the decree holder i.e., the first respondent.

anchor.surface_text: On September 23, 1958 the District Judge sent a letter to the Subordinate Judge asking him number to pay the sale proceeds of the house to the decree bolder i.e., the first respondent.

facts.text: On November 20, 1958, the Collector of Aurangabad made an order distraining the amount of Rs. 9,672/- out of the sale proceeds under s. 119 of the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, the Collector of Aurangabad made an order on November 20, 1958, distraining the amount of Rs. 9,672/- out of the sale proceeds under s. 119 of the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act  Hyd. Act VIII of 1317F. .

facts.text: The 1st respondent made an application to the trial court challenging the validity of the order of the Collector.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the 1st respondent made an application to the trial companyrt challenging the validity of the order of the Collector.

facts.text: The Subordinate Judge held that the Civil Court had no jurisdiction to set aside the order of the Collector.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge held that the Civil Court had numberjurisdiction to set aside, revise or modify the order of the Collector and it companyld be done only by the Superior Revenue Authorities.

facts.text: The 1st respondent preferred First Appeal No. 341 of 1959 in the Bombay High Court from the order of the Subordinate Judge.

anchor.surface_text: From the order of the Subordinate Judge the 1st respondent preferred an appeal being First Appeal No. 341 of 1959 in the Bombay High Court

facts.text: Naik, J. by judgment dated June 22, 1960 held that Government was entitled to priority for sales-tax arrears over the claim of the 1st respondent and dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was heard by Naik, J. who by his judgment dated June 22, 1960 held that in view of the provisions companytained in ss. 104 and It 9 of the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act the Gov- ernment was entitled to priority for the arrears of sales- tax due from the second respondent over the claim of the 1st respondent The learned Judge accordingly dismissed the First Appeal.

facts.text: A Division Bench consisting of Patel and K. K. Desai, JJ. allowed the Letters Patent Appeal by judgment dated December 17, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: From the judgment of Naik, J. the 1st respondent took the matter in appeal under the Letters Patent. A Division Bench companysisting of Patel and K. K. Desai, JJ. allowed the appeal by their judgment dated December 17, 1962 holding that S. 119 of the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act applied only to property which was in the custody and possession of the judgment-debtor and number in the custody or possession of a Court.

facts.text: Sales-tax arrears were due for the years 1950-51 to 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: On August 17, 1958 the Sales Tax Officer, Aurangabad Circle wrote a letter to the District Judge, Aurangabad pointing out that a sum of Rs. 9,672/- and odd was due to the Government from the second respondent on account of arrears of sales-tax for the years 1950-51 to 1955-56.

facts.text: The Collector of Aurangabad sent the order of distraint to the Subordinate Judge requesting him to remit Rs. 9,672/- to the Sales Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the Collector of Aurangabad sent the order of distraint to the Subordinate Judge requesting him to remit to the Sales Tax Officer the amount of Rs. 9,672/- out of the amount of sale proceeds deposited in his Court.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the order of distraint dated November 20, 1958 by the Collector is legally valid.

anchor.surface_text: The first question to be companysidered in this appeal is whether the order of distraint dated November 20, 1958 made by the Collector of Aurangabad is legally valid.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that arrears of sales-tax do not have priority over the dues of the 1st respondent under the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, Counsel for the appelants has number been able to make good his argument on this aspect of the case.

facts.text: There is no proof that the English Common Law doctrine of priority of Crown debts was given judicial recognition in Hyderabad State prior to January 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: We are, however, unable to apply the English Common Law doctrine of priority of Crown debts in this case, because there is numberproof that the doctrine was given judicial recognition in the  1  56 1. T. R. 91  2  19671 2 C.R. 170.  3   1920  65 Law.Ed. 315. territory of Hyderabad State prior to January 26, 1950 when the Constitution was brought into force.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 17, 1962 of the Bombay High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 29 of 1960.
Letters Patent Appeal No. 29 of 1960. T. Desai, R. Ganapathy Iyer and S. P. Nayyar, for the appellants. Hans Raj Sawhney, P. C. Bhartari and 0. C. Mathur, for the respondents.

issues.text: whether the order of distraint dated November 20, 1958 made by the Collector of Aurangabad is legally valid

anchor.surface_text: The first question to be considered in this appeal is whether the order of distraint dated November 20, 1958 made by the Collector of Aurangabad is legally valid. The order of the Collector was made under S. 13

issues.text: whether the debt due to the Government in respect of arrears of sales-tax has priority over the dues of respondent No. 1

anchor.surface_text: We proceed to consider the next question arising in this appeal, viz., whether the debt due to the Government in respect of arrears of sales-tax has priority over the dues of respondent No. 1. It appears that the sales-tax was due for the years 1950 - 51 to 1955-56, i.e., for a period of six years.

issues.text: whether the appellants are entitled to claim priority towards payment of sales-tax according to the Common Law doctrine of Priority of Crown debts quite apart from the provisions of the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act

anchor.surface_text: We pass on to consider the next question arising in this case, namely, whether the appellants are entitled to claim priority towards payment of sales-tax according to the Common Law doctrine of Priority of Crown debts quite apart from the provisions of the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act.

holdings.text: the procedure followed by the Collector is justified by the provision of s. 119 and there is nothing in the language or context of the section which prohibits the Collector from making an order of distraint with regard to the movable property in the custody and possession of a Court

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the Collector of Aurangabad sent the order of distraint to the Subordinate Judge requesting him to remit to the Sales Tax Officer the amount of Rs. 9,672/- out of the amount of sale proceeds deposited in his Court. We are of the opinion that the procedure followed by the Collector is justified by the provision of s. 119 and there is nothing in the language or context of the section which prohibits the Collector from making an order of distraint with regard to the movable property in the custody and possession of a Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Language of s.119 is general empowering Tahsildar to distrain defaulter's movable property without restriction as to custody; High Court's construction erroneous.

holdings.text: the priority specified in that section [s.104] applies only in respect of land revenue and not in respect of other taxes. In respect of other taxes, we consider that only the procedure for recovery under s.116 applies and not the substantive law of priority under s.104 of the Land Revenue Act

anchor.surface_text: Section 144 enumerates the nature of taxes in respect of which the provision under the Land Revenue Act could be adopted for recovery. But the language of s. 104 makes it clear that the priority specified in that section applies only in respect of land revenue and not in respect of other taxes. In respect of other taxes, we consider that only the procedure for recovery under s. 116 applies and not the substantive law of priority under s. 104 of he Land Revenue, Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.104 expressly limits priority to land revenue demands despite s.144 allowing recovery procedures for other government sums including taxes as land revenue arrears.

holdings.text: We are, however, unable to apply the English Common Law doctrine of priority of Crown debts in this case, because there is no proof that the doctrine was given judicial recognition in the territory of Hyderabad State prior to January 26, 1950 when the Constitution was brought into force

anchor.surface_text: We are, however, unable to apply the English Common Law doctrine of priority of Crown debts in this case, because there is no proof that the doctrine was given judicial recognition in the territory of Hyderabad State prior to January 26, 1950 when the Constitution was brought into force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Doctrine applicable via Art.372 only if judicially recognized pre-Constitution in the specific territory; proven for British India but no evidence for Hyderabad State.

precedents.citation: Secretary of State in Council for India v. Bombay Landing Shipping Co. Limited 1

anchor.surface_text: Secretary of State in Council for India v. Bombay Landing Shipping Co. Limited 1 , in which it was held that a judgment debt due to the Crown was in Bombay entitled to the same precedence in execution as a like judgment debt in England, if there is no special legislative provision affecting that right in the particular case.

precedents.case_name: Secretary of State in Council for India v. Bombay Landing Shipping Co. Limited
precedents.cited_proposition: judgment debt due to the Crown entitled to precedence in execution as in England absent special legislation
precedents.cited_holding: a judgment debt due to the Crown was in Bombay entitled to the same precedence in execution as a like judgment debt in England, if there is no special legislative provision affecting that right

precedents.citation: Bank of India v. John Bowman 2

anchor.surface_text: The same view has been taken by the Bombay High Court in a later case-Bank of India v. John Bowman 2 -in which Chagla, C.J., pointed out that the priority given to the Crown was not on the basis of its debt being a judgment-debt or a debt arising out of statute, but the principle was that if the debts were of equal degree and the Crown and the subject were equal, the Crowns right would prevail over that of the subject.

precedents.case_name: Bank of India v. John Bowman
precedents.cited_proposition: Crown priority where debts of equal degree
precedents.cited_holding: the priority given to the Crown was not on the basis of its debt being a judgment-debt or a debt arising out of statute, but the principle was that if the debts were of equal degree and the Crown and the subject were equal, the Crowns right would prevail over that of the subject

precedents.citation: Manickam Chettiar v. Income-tax Officer, Madura 3
precedents.case_name: Manickam Chettiar v. Income-tax Officer, Madura
precedents.cited_proposition: income-tax debt priority over private debts; court inherent power for Crown payment
precedents.cited_holding: the income-tax debt had priority over private debts and the court had inherent power to make an order for payment of moneys due to the Crown

precedents.citation: Kaka Mohamed Ghouse Sahib Co. v. United Commercial Syndicate 4

anchor.surface_text: A similar view has been expressed by the High Court in Kaka Mohamed Ghouse Sahib Co. v. United Commercial Syndicate 4 . All these authorities have been quoted with approval by this Court in

precedents.case_name: Kaka Mohamed Ghouse Sahib Co. v. United Commercial Syndicate
precedents.cited_proposition: similar view on Crown debt priority

precedents.citation: Builders Supply Corporation v. Union of India 1
precedents.case_name: Builders Supply Corporation v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Government priority for income-tax arrears over unsecured creditors; English common law doctrine recognized in British India pre-1950 and continues under Art. 372
precedents.cited_holding: the Government of India was entitled to claim priority for arrears of income-tax due to it from a citizen over debts from him to unsecured creditors and that the English common law doctrine of the priority of Crown debts has been given judicial recognition in the territory known as British India prior to 1950 in regard to the recovery of tax dues in priority to other private debts of the tax-payer

precedents.citation: The Superintendent Remembrancer of Legal Affairs, West Bengal v. The Corporation of Calcutta, 2
precedents.case_name: Superintendent Remembrancer of Legal Affairs, West Bengal v. Corporation of Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: rule that State not bound by statute unless named or by implication not accepted in India; it is rule of construction not substantive law
precedents.cited_holding: the rule of English Common law that the State was not bound by the provisions of a statute unless it was expressly named or brought in by necessary implication, was not accepted as a rule of construction throughout India and therefore it has not become law of the land

precedents.citation: ff. Snowden Marshall v. People of the State of New York 1
precedents.case_name: Snowden & Marshall v. People of the State of New York
precedents.cited_proposition: State has common law prerogative right of priority over unsecured creditors
precedents.cited_holding: the State of New York has the common law prerogative right of priority over unsecured creditors

The letter from the Sales Tax Officer asserts a sales tax sum due to the Government, claiming it satisfies the concept of government sums (including taxes) recoverable as arrears of land revenue under Section 144 HLRA.
The fact of the Sales Tax Officer writing a letter pointing out the sales tax sum due to the Government triggers the issue of whether such arrears have priority over respondent No. 1's dues.
Holding h1 interprets the language and context of the section (Section 116 HLRA) as not prohibiting the Collector's action, supporting its application.

anchor.surface_text: e judgment-debtor and number in the custody or possession of a Court. It was observed by the Division Bench that the provisions of the Hyderabad Land

edges.explanation: Holding justifying Collector's procedure under s.119 addresses validity of distraint order

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the Collector of Aurangabad sent the order of distraint to the Subordinate Judge requesting him to remit to the Sales Tax Officer the amount of Rs. 9,672/- out of the amount of sale proceeds deposited in his Court. We are of the opinion that the procedure followed by the Collector is justified by the provision of s. 119 and there is nothing in the language or context of the section which prohibits the Collector from making an order of distraint with regard to the movable property in the custody and possession of a Court.
For these reasons we hold that the judgment of the Bombay High Court dated December 17, 1962 in Letters Patent Appeal No. 29 of 1960 must be affirmed and this appeal must be dismissed with

anchor.surface_text: erty. Such distraint shall be made by officers or clerks appointed by him for this work. The High Court has taken the view that s. 119 can only apply

edges.explanation: Holding denying priority for other taxes addresses sales-tax priority over respondent dues

anchor.surface_text: Section 144 enumerates the nature of taxes in respect of which the provision under the Land Revenue Act could be adopted for recovery. But the language of s. 104 makes it clear that the priority specified in that section applies only in respect of land revenue and not in respect of other taxes. In respect of other taxes, we consider that only the procedure for recovery under s. 116 applies and not the substantive law of priority under s. 104 of he Land Revenue, Act.
For these reasons we hold that the judgment of the Bombay High Court dated December 17, 1962 in Letters Patent Appeal No. 29 of 1960 must be affirmed and this appeal must be dismissed with

anchor.surface_text: We are, however, unable to apply the English Common Law doctrine of priority of Crown debts in this case, because there is no proof that the doctrine was given judicial recognition in the territory of Hyderabad State prior to January 26, 1950 when the Constitution was brought into force.
For these reasons we hold that the judgment of the Bombay High Court dated December 17, 1962 in Letters Patent Appeal No. 29 of 1960 must be affirmed and this appeal must be dismissed with
